facts.text: Appeal by special leave in C.A. No. 1946 of 1968 from judgment and order dated September 29,1967 of Delhi High Court in I.T. Reference No. 46-D of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. C. A. No. 1946 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and ordered dated September 29,1967 of the Delhi High Court in 1. T. Reference No. 46-D of 1962.

facts.text: The assessee and his wife owned a large number of shares in a private limited company engaged in the business of running hotels.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee and his wife owned a large number of shares in a private limited companypany engaged in the business of running hotels.

facts.text: By virtue of Art. 109 of the Articles of Association, the assessee became the first Managing Director on terms agreed in an agreement dated November 20,1955 between himself and the company.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of Art. 109 of the Articles of Association of the said companypany, the assessed became the first Managing Direction on terms companyditions agreed to and embodied in an agreement dated November 20,1955 between himself and the companypany.

facts.text: Under the agreement, the assessee was to receive Rs. 2,000/- per month, Rs. 500/p.m. as car allowance, 10 per cent of gross profits of the company and free board and lodging in the hotel.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said agreement, the assessee was to receive Rs. 2,000/- per month, a fixed sum of Rs. 500/p.m. as car allowance, 10 per cent of gross profits of the companypany and he and his wife were entitled to free board and lodging in the hotel.

facts.text: For assessment year 1956-57, accounting year ending 30th September 1955, assessee assessed on Rs. 53,913/- as 10% of gross profits.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1956-57 for which the accounting year is the year ending 30th September 1955, the assesses was assessed in respect of Rs. 53,913/- payable to him as 10 of the gross profits of the companypany

facts.text: Assessee gave up Rs. 53,913/- soon after accounts finalised but before passed by general meeting of shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: which he gave up soon after the accounts were finalised but before they were passed by the general meeting of the shareholders.

facts.text: Amount given up because company would not be making net profits if commission paid.

anchor.surface_text: The above amount was given up by him because the companypany would number be making net profits if the stipulated companymission was paid to him.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Tribunal and High Court held Rs. 53,913/- taxable as salary under s.7 and accrued during previous year.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the Tribunal and on a reference under s. 66 1  the High Court have all held that the 10 companymission on gross profits amounting to Rs. 53,913/- was taxable as salary under s. 7 of the Act

facts.text: Questions referred to High Court under s.66(1): Whether Rs.53,913/- revenue receipt of previous year; chargeable u/s7 or s.10; if u/s10, deduction u/s10(1) or 10(2).

anchor.surface_text: The questions of law which were referred to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act are as follows - Whether the sum of Rs. 53,913/- was a revenue receipt of the assessee of the previous year ? Whether the amount is chargeable under s. 7 or s. 10 of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: High Court answered first question affirmatively in favour of revenue, second as chargeable under s.7, did not answer third.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and in favour of the revenue, and on the second question it was of the view that the amount payable as companymission was chargeable under S. 7 as salary and number under S. 10 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court on November 9, 1971 directed Tribunal for supplementary statement on third question.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up earlier, this Court on November 9, 1971 companysidered it necessary to call for a further statement of the case from the Tribunal on the third question

facts.text: Tribunal in supplementary statement held assessee not entitled to deduction of Rs.53,913/- u/s10(1) or 10(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its supplementary statement of case has answered the question against the assessee and in favour of the Department in holding that the assessee is number entitled to a deduction of the, sum of Rs. 53,913/-

facts.text: Not disputed that commission is revenue receipt and accrued to assessee in year of account.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the companymission payable to him would be a revenue receipt number is it disputed that if it is chargeable under s. 7 numberother question would arise having regard to the finding based on the decision in Morvi Industries case  supra  that the amount of Rs. 53,913/- had accrued

facts.text: Assessee contended that no master-servant relationship, he is agent or independent contractor, commission is business income not salary.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the assessee, it was companytended that in order to assess the income as salary it must be held that there was a relationship of master and servant between the companypany and the assessee.

facts.text: Agreement clause k: assessee can resign with 3 months notice; company can terminate if not diligent or not acting in interests.

anchor.surface_text: Cl.  k  of the agreement dated 29-11-1955 stipulates - That the said Ram Pershad shall be at liberty to resign the said office upon giving three months numberice to the companypany of his desire to do so. If the said Managing Director is found to be acting otherwise than in. the interests of the companypany

facts.text: Supreme Court holds remuneration payable to assessee as Managing Director is salary under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: We would therefore hold that the remuneration payable to him is salary. In this view, the other questions need number be companysidered, and the appeal is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Art. 109 provided assessee as Managing Director for 20 years on terms of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 109 of the articles of association before its amendment and relevant for the period which we are companysidering provided that he shall be the Managing Director of the companypany for 20 years on terms and companyditions embodied in the agreement.

facts.text: Assessee is Ram Pershad.

anchor.surface_text: the said Ram Pershad shall be at liberty

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: the appeal is dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: whether the 10 per cent gross profits payable to the assessee under the terms of the agreement appointing him as the Managing Director is liable to be assessed as salary or under the head income from business

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore necessary for us to consider whether the 10 per cent gross profits payable to the assessee under the terms of the agreement appointing him as the Managing Director is liable to be assessed as salary or under the head income from business.

arguments.claim: The amount of Rs. 53,913/- had not accrued to the assessee in the previous year and thus not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that the amount given up by him was not liable to be included in his total income because the amount had not accrued to him at all, at any rate, in the accounting year ended 31st March 1956 and that even assuming that it had accrued in the account year ended 31st March 1956, it is not taxable under s. 7 or s. 10

arguments.claim: Rs. 53,913/- commission taxable as salary under s.7 and accrued during previous year.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: umber under S. 10 of the Act. On this view, it did number think it necessary to answer the third question. When the matter came up earlier, this Court

arguments.court_reasoning: Not disputed; confirmed accrual and chargeability under s.7.

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal held no deduction u/s.10(1) or 10(2); not necessary to consider as held salary u/s.7.

arguments.claim: No master-servant relationship; assessee is agent or independent contractor; commission is business income u/s.10 not salary u/s.7.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the assessee, it was contended that in order to assess the income as salary it must be held that there was a relationship of master and servant between the company and the assessee. For such a relationship to exist, it must be shown that the employee must be subject to the supervision and control of the employer... Applying these tests, it is submitted that the appointment of the assessee as a Managing Director is not that of a servant but as an agent of the company and accordingly the commission payable to him is income from business and not salary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed is a servant or an agent. In each case the principle for ascertainment remains the same. Though an agent as such is number a servant, a servant is

arguments.court_reasoning: Supervisory control test not universal; articles of association and agreement indicate servant status with board control, dismissal rights; remuneration salary u/s.7.

arguments.claim: Supervisory control test determines servant vs agent: no direct control/supervision means agent.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that for ascertaining whether a person is a servant or an agent, a rough and ready test is, whether, under the terms of his employment, the employer exercises a supervisory control in respect of the work entrusted to him... But this test is not universal in its application...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . If he is to take the employer or any other person at his request from place A to place B the employer does number supervise the manner in which he d

arguments.court_reasoning: Test acknowledged but not determinative alone; not universal (examples: doctor, chauffeur); greater control indicates servant.

arguments.claim: Managing Director's remuneration assessable as salary u/s.7 if contract of service per articles and agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, whether or not a Managing Director is a servant of the company apart from his being a Director can only be determined by the articles of association and the terms of his employment.

arguments.claim: Articles 109,136-142 and agreement show control by Board, dismissal rights; indicia of service present: servant not agent.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 109... provided that he shall be the Managing Director... for 20 years on terms... Art. 136... general management... in the hands of the Managing Director... Cl. k of the agreement... company in General Meeting may terminate his services... The control... exercised... by the Board of Directors... indicative of his being employed as a servant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assessees work whenever they deem it necessary. Every power which is given to the Managing Director therefore emanates from the articles of assoc

arguments.claim: Board manages business u/s.17(2) Companies Act 1913, Table A Reg.71; controls MD.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 17(2) of the Indian Companies Act 1913 Regulation No. 71 of Table A which enjoins that the business of the company shall be managed by the directors... Since the Board of Directors are to manage the business of the Company they have every right to control and supervise the assessee's work.

arguments.claim: Indicia of contract of service: master's selection, remuneration payment, control of method, right to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: In certain cases it has been laid down that the indicia of a contract of service are (a) the master's power of selection of the servant (b) the payment of wages or other remunerations (c) the master's right to control the method of doing the work and (d) the master's right to suspension or dismissal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applied to facts showing servant status.

arguments.claim: Contract with MD is contract of service not for services (Anderson precedent).

anchor.surface_text: Qua managing director he is a party to a contract with the company, and this contract is a contract of employment more specifically I am of opinion that it is a contract of service and not a contract for service.

arguments.claim: In Armstrong Smith, MD under articles is servant, remuneration salary u/s.7.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. Armstrong Smith... it was held that the remuneration was taxable under s. 7 and not under s. 12 of the Act... the relationship between the company and the assessee... depends upon the articles.

arguments.court_reasoning: Similar to present articles creating contractual employment.

arguments.claim: Cases like Manmohan Das, Qamar Shafi, Lakshminarayan distinguished: different facts, no such control.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax Manmohan Das... the treasurer was not a servant... In Qamar Shaffi Tyabji... neither servant nor sub-agent... In Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal... indicia inconsistent with servant.

arguments.court_reasoning: Present case has board control unlike those.

arguments.claim: High Court correctly held chargeable under s.7 not s.10.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and in favour of the revenue, and on the second question it was of the view that the amount payable as commission was chargeable under S. 7 as salary and not under S. 10 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assessees work whenever they deem it necessary. Every power which is given to the Managing Director therefore emanates from the articles of assoc

arguments.claim: No deduction u/s.10(1) or 10(2) if under s.10.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its supplementary statement of case has answered the question against the assessee... holding that the assessee is not entitled to a deduction of the sum of Rs. 53,913/- either under s.10(1) or 10(2) of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assessees work whenever they deem it necessary. Every power which is given to the Managing Director therefore emanates from the articles of assoc

arguments.court_reasoning: Not reached as held under s.7.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 53,913/- was a revenue receipt of the assessee of the previous year and had accrued to the assessee in the year of account.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the commission payable to him would be a revenue receipt nor is it disputed that if it is chargeable under s. 7 no other question would arise having regard to the finding based on the decision in Morvi Industries case supra that the amount of Rs. 53,913/- had accrued

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties do not dispute; supported by Morvi Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax precedent on accrual despite later relinquishment.

holdings.text: The amount is chargeable under s. 7 as salary and not under s. 10.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and in favour of the revenue, and on the second question it was of the view that the amount payable as commission was chargeable under S. 7 as salary and not under S. 10 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court; remuneration to Managing Director taxable as salary per s.7.

holdings.text: The assessee is not entitled to a deduction of Rs. 53,913/- under s.10(1) or s.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its supplementary statement of case has answered the question against the assessee and in favour of the Department in holding that the assessee is not entitled to a deduction of the, sum of Rs. 53,913/- either under s.10(1) or 10(2) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's supplementary statement accepted but not reached as amount held taxable under s.7.

holdings.text: The remuneration payable to the assessee as Managing Director is salary under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: We would therefore hold that the remuneration payable to him is salary. In this view, the other questions need not be considered, and the appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Articles of association (Arts. 109, 136-142) and agreement show Board control, supervision, dismissal rights, indicia of service; contract of service not for services; supervisory control test not universal; followed Armstrong Smith, distinguished Manmohan Das, Qamar Shafi, Lakshminarayan.

holdings.text: The assessee as Managing Director was employed as a servant of the company, not an agent.

anchor.surface_text: These terms are inconsistent with the plea that he is an agent of the company and not a servant. The control and supervision is exercised and is exercisable in terms of the articles of association by the Board of Directors and the company in its general meeting.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Control by Board per articles (e.g., Arts. 139, 142), termination clause in agreement (cl. k), s.17(2) Companies Act; indicia present (selection, remuneration, control, dismissal).

holdings.text: The rough and ready test of supervisory control is not universal in its application.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that for ascertaining whether a person is a servant or an agent, a rough and ready test is, whether, under the terms of his employment, the employer exercises a supervisory control in respect of the work entrusted to him... But this test is not universal in its application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examples like doctor, chauffeur show limitations; greater independence suggests agency.
